course.subject: LIFS
course.name: Neuroethology: From Neurons to Behavior
course.description: This course will introduce the exciting discoveries by neuroscientists who investigate the biological foundations of behavior. Much success in this arena has come from the study of animals whose behavioral requirements for survival can be clearly specified and whose nervous systems reveal characteristics to support species-specific behaviors. Noteworthy examples include echolocation in bats, prey localization in barn owls, and communication in songbirds. Our goal will be to integrate data from studies at different levels of the system, and our weekly discussions will center on themes such as ecological constraints on behavior and dedicated neural systems. Students without the prerequisites but possess relevant knowledge may seek instructor's approval for enrolling in the course.
course.prerequisites: LIFS 3040 OR LIFS 3240 OR LIFS 4950

reviews.author: Donald Siu
reviews.title: Quite a novel course
reviews.comment_content: It teaches the interplay between physiology and animal behavior. It is a novel topic that is seldom taught in HKUST.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Moss is a visiting professor from Johns Hopkins University. She was very experienced and well-known in the field of animal behavior. She was very nice to students, and she even watched bats' behavior with her students.
reviews.comment_grading: Prof. Moss is lenient in terms of grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
The only tough thing about the course is about its workload. The workload is quite high--- one mid-term, two projects.

But if you are experienced in reading biology papers, you should be okay.
